awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of code-switching on emotional processing
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation research project examines the effect of switching languages, or code-switching, on the emotional reactivity to emotional words. Emotional reactivity is defined as the differences in how we react to emotionally charged words such as ‘sweetheart’, ‘disgust’, and neutral words, such as ‘door’, ‘cup’, as observed using various experimental techniques. Researchers have a good understanding of the language acquisition factors shaping bilinguals’ emotional reactivity to words in their first and second language. Nevertheless, it is yet unknown how switching between languages, a common bilingual conversational act, affects emotional reactivity. Spurred by the work of sociolinguists and psychologists, this project aims to ascertain whether code-switching reduces emotionality and its findings will advance knowledge about the relationship between code-switching and emotionality. 

Sociolinguists have found that code-switches frequently occur before emotional words. This pattern suggests that code-switches provide some type of benefits to bilingual comprehension. Psycholinguists have found that code-switched paragraphs increase objectivity by potentially reducing emotionality, more than passages entirely in the first or second language. Moreover, emotion regulation or reduction and code-switch comprehension result in similar neurocognitive responses. It is thus likely that code-switches help reduce bilinguals’ emotional reactivity to emotional words. Two experiments will be conducted to ascertain the effect of code-switching on emotional reactivity. In the first experiment, Spanish-English bilinguals' eye-movements associated with emotional vs. neutral words embedded in Spanish, English, and code-switched sentences will be compared. The second experiment will use electroencephalography time-locked to events (Event-Related Potentials) to compare the electrophysiological signatures of emotional vs. neutral word processing in the three language conditions. The hypothesis is that the differences between emotional and neutral words would be the smallest in the code-switched sentences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bilinguals in the presence of other bilinguals may engage in code-switching, which involves the fluid alternation between languages. Despite its ubiquity among bilingual communities, lab-based experimental studies frequently find delayed comprehension, such as when reading times are slower when encountering a code-switch as compared to same language continuations. Yet sociolinguistic studies indicate that code-switching may occur under certain pragmatic contexts. For example, a code-switch is more likely to occur before emotionally charged or taboo content. This project uses psycholinguistic methodology to empirically investigate this sociopragmatic function of code-switching. Specifically, this project uses eye-tracking to study whether biligual readers associate code-switches as signalling upcoming negatively valenced linguistic input. Spanish-English bilingual participants read neutral, positively valent, and negatively valent sentences in English-only, Spanish-only, and Spanish-to-English code-switched sentences. In the critical comparison, bilinguals demonstrated a facilitated reading time (i.e., a reduced negativity effect) when encountering a negatively valent word in code-switching as compared to English-only sentences. This finding is significant as reading times were measured on English words in both instances. Moreover, this facilation effect could not be accounted by proficiency. This study begins to more closely align tightly controlled experimental designs used in psycholinguistic methodlogy with more ecological and naturalistic bilingual language practices as documented by sociolinguists. The findings also contradict a strictly deficit-based approach to code-switching, indicating that under certain pragmatic contexts, code-switching may actually lead to facilitated processing.

The research findings have been communicated at national and international venues on bilingualism and psycholinguistic research and have been published in peer-reviewed volumes. The award also aided in the recruitment and training of undergraduate Latinx research assistants, thus providing training opportunites to underrepresented groups in linguistics. A future EEG study that is an extension of the current findings is planned to further investigate the neurocognitive reflexes of reading emotionally valent stimuli in code-switched and non-switched sentences. This project is among a growing trend within psycholinguistic research to acknowledge how varied language use and other experiential factors may impact how language is processed and regulated in the human mind and highlights the dynamic nature of language processing.
